title: Prime + Two Powers Form
content:
An integer n has the form **p + 2^k + 2^l** if there exist a prime p and non-negative integers k, l such that n equals their sum.

This is the representation we're studying - most odd integers have it.

title: Set S
content:
S is the set of all positive integers WITH the form p + 2^k + 2^l.

Most odd integers belong to S.

title: Exceptional Set A
content:
**A** is the set of odd positive integers WITHOUT the form p + 2^k + 2^l.

This is the central object of Erdős Problem #9. The question is whether A has positive upper density.

title: Counting Function
content:
countA(N) counts exceptional odd integers up to N.

The question is whether countA(N)/N has a positive limit.

title: Upper Density
content:
The **upper density** of a set A is lim sup of |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / N.

Positive upper density means a positive proportion of integers are in A asymptotically.

title: Erdős Problem #9 (OPEN)
content:
**Main Question:** Does the set A of odd integers not of the form p + 2^k + 2^l have positive upper density?

This is equivalent to asking if there exists δ > 0 such that countA(N) ≥ δN for large N.

title: Schinzel's Result
content:
**Schinzel:** There are infinitely many exceptional odd integers.

Credited by Erdős in 1977, but no reference given. This is the starting point.

title: A is Unbounded
content:
For every N, there exists an exceptional odd integer greater than N.

This follows immediately from Schinzel's result.

title: Crocker's Bound (1971)
content:
**Crocker (1971):** countA(N) ≫ log log N.

The first quantitative lower bound. Very slow growth - doubly logarithmic.

title: Pan's Bound (2011)
content:
**Pan (2011):** For any ε > 0, countA(N) ≫ N^{1-ε}.

Massive improvement over Crocker - from log log N to almost linear! But still not positive density.
mathContext: The gap from N^{1-ε} to linear N is what remains to be closed.

title: Covering Systems Fail
content:
**Erdős's Observation:** Integers of the form p + 2^k + 2^l exist in EVERY arithmetic progression.

This means covering system methods cannot prove positive density for A.
mathContext: Covering systems work by finding arithmetic progressions that miss the target set. But every AP meets S.

title: S Meets All Progressions
content:
For any arithmetic progression {a, a+d, a+2d, ...}, there exists n in S with n ≡ a (mod d).

This formalizes why covering systems are insufficient.

title: 1 is Exceptional
content:
1 ∈ A: 1 is odd and cannot be p + 2^k + 2^l.

Proof: Any prime p ≥ 2, and 2^k, 2^l ≥ 1, so p + 2^k + 2^l ≥ 4 > 1.

title: 3 is Exceptional
content:
3 ∈ A: 3 is odd and cannot be p + 2^k + 2^l.

Proof: Similar to 1 - the minimum is p + 2^0 + 2^0 = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4 > 3.

title: Linear Bound Would Solve
content:
If we could prove countA(N) ≥ cN for some c > 0, the problem would be solved.

This is equivalent to positive upper density.
